meeting_annotations.speaker: Hongfu Liu
meeting_annotations.transcript: the model adaptation in a new scenario.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Christoph Thaiss (UPenn)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Right, in a way it's a model validation to to a population that has a relatively sparse agreement with with the original model in terms of the data matrix. Um, and and in the case of those the the example that I just mentioned, it was uh it was surprisingly poor how how uh applicable the model was. So the question is is this something that is going to get better as we standardize measurements across different uh geographical areas or is there something intrinsic to geographic heterogeneity in the human population that that we need to factor into the model to to improve the predictability.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Hongfu Liu
meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay, but here is the thing for currently we just collect as many as possible of the measurements to put into the model.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Hongfu Liu
meeting_annotations.transcript: So hopefully with the all the measurements we we have, we can get some better performance.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Curt Horvath (Northwestern)
meeting_annotations.transcript: But in the case you mentioned, you know, it could just be that in the different communities, you have different diets, you have different genetics, you know, different stresses. So for medical health prediction, you have to take into uh these local considerations as well, I would imagine. Same thing would apply uh you know, in in cases of zoonotic uh uh transmission.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Nicole Eikmeier (she/her) @Grinnell
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: The screen shows a document titled "Breakout Discussion" with a list of questions related to big data, clinics, and biomarkers. The content remains static during this segment.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Christoph Thaiss (UPenn)
meeting_annotations.transcript: I completely agree. That's that's actually exactly what my what my lab is studying. How how these uh um sort of lifestyle factors other than the traditional ones we're collecting influence the outcome of uh infectious disease.
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: The screen shows a document titled "Breakout Discussion" with a list of questions related to big data, clinics, and biomarkers. The content remains static during this segment.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Nicole Eikmeier (she/her) @Grinnell
meeting_annotations.transcript: I mean, I think uh Christoph, what you've said is actually not a unique problem to this space. It's it's kind of like a universal problem to modeling and I'm I'm assuming that these studies that you're talking about were using some sort of like machine learning or neural networks or something. Like the the models can't predict the the outcomes of data that they haven't seen. And and that's just that's reality. You you train these models on whatever data you have and then it can do really well on that data, but not on on other things. So um.
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: The screen shows a document titled "Breakout Discussion" with a list of questions related to big data, clinics, and biomarkers. The content remains static during this segment.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Christoph Thaiss (UPenn)
meeting_annotations.transcript: That's true, but at the same time we were hoping that there would be some kind of biological ground truth um that's that the model can predict no matter the the training set. Um, but it seems at least in this case it wasn't the case. And and as you mentioned, there are there are many more examples of of this uh sort of poor performance across across different models or or across models that were generated on different populations.
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: The screen shows a document titled "Breakout Discussion" with a list of questions related to big data, clinics, and biomarkers. The content remains static during this segment.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Nicole Eikmeier (she/her) @Grinnell
meeting_annotations.transcript: So solve machine learning. Goal one.
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: The screen shows a document titled "Breakout Discussion" with a list of questions related to big data, clinics, and biomarkers. The content remains static during this segment.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Mark Wilber
meeting_annotations.transcript: Just maybe also maybe just understand a little bit more like the fundamental fundamental mechanisms. I guess in my mind sometimes at least in our field, I think the tradition is very much like compartmental mechanistic models and now there's just sort of trend of machine learning which gives you a ton of power in certain spaces. Um but I think maybe not losing sight of kind of that biological mechanistic understanding that potentially would have better out of sample prediction in some cases, but I guess finding that balance I think is maybe where where we need to be looking.
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: The screen shows a document titled "Breakout Discussion" with a list of questions related to big data, clinics, and biomarkers. The content remains static during this segment.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Matt Erdman - USDA APHIS
meeting_annotations.transcript: Mark, how do you how do you do that? Do you is that almost always going to require multi-disciplinary collaborations with people with different expertises so that a model, you know, Hongfu mentioned that a lot of times we just grab whatever data we can, right? We just take it all. And there's a risk to that when you just throw everything into a model.
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: The screen shows a document titled "Breakout Discussion" with a list of questions related to big data, clinics, and biomarkers. The content remains static during this segment.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Mark Wilber
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I don't I don't have a good answer to that. Um I don't know exactly know how we do that, but I do think and I do think for some systems and so I was talking to somebody yesterday and he pointed me to a really interesting influenza paper. So for some systems where we have so this is it's funny. It's almost like a as a little bit of a not a totally counter example to what was just said because I don't know if they did sort of the out of sample from like Texas to France in that in that case. Um but what they were seeing is that they'd been a bunch of like CDC does the influenza prediction um kind of contest yearly. Um and you know, there's a variety of, you know, machine learn learning models, more mechanistic models and sort of hybrids. And so this group developed kind of a really simple kind of SIR type model compartmental model with sort of a hybrid um kind of a mechanistic statistical approach that was layered on. And so they were able to capture these kind of general mechanistic trends which you would expect given kind of the general mechanisms that we know influenza spreads by. Um and then we're able to sort of count for some of the the systematic biases with kind of an a mechanistic black box thing. We don't really know why we have these systematic biases, but we can use mechanisms to predict sort of the broader trend.
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: The screen shows a document titled "Breakout Discussion" with a list of questions related to big data, clinics, and biomarkers. The content remains static during this segment.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Hongfu Liu
meeting_annotations.transcript: So uh go back to the feature problem is so can say what machine learning do just we want feed our equation Y equals fX. So X is the data we collect and F is something we kind of of interest. We call this a label here and the F is the mapping function from the X to to Y. So why we want to collect as many as possible measurement? The reason is if we know what X can indicate Y, we do not need to collect so many data, right? So the the reason is we do not know what kind of measurement can help on the Y on the label prediction.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Hongfu Liu
meeting_annotations.transcript: If we know that, we can definitely just use the partial data, that will be great and shrink the model size. And uh kind of we do not know this answer. So that's the reason we do this. And we also want to know with so many features measurement, what kind of measurement plays the key role in the model prediction. And this can be also partially answered by the current machine learning model can break the black box, give some understanding and interpretation.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Audrey Ruple, Virginia Tech, (she/her)
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: The screen shows a document titled "Breakout Discussion" with a list of questions related to big data, clinics, and biomarkers. The content remains static during this segment.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Erik Procko
meeting_annotations.transcript: I have more of a question to pose to people that do modeling regarding using sequencing data. So with obviously the COVID pandemic and all the surveillance, there's tons and tons of sequences that are now deposited. Um and often there's not much more than just geographical location to go with that sequence. Um there's also lots of sequence information for you know, different influenzas. Um is there, you know, if you want to forward predict what the next surge might be, what you know, how the antigens will shift? Is there key information which is being missed? You know, what what new information do we need in all of that sequence information to be able to you know, prepare for changes in the future and and you know, plan how for example, a SARS CoV2 might might change and have some new variant surge? I don't know if anyone's got thoughts on that.
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: The screen shows a document titled "Breakout Discussion" with a list of questions related to big data, clinics, and biomarkers. The content remains static during this segment.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jason Ladner (he/him) | NAU
meeting_annotations.transcript: I'm not a modeler, but just to sort of chime in. I mean, I think here it's really important to combine data sources, right? The sequence data alone isn't going to allow you to make a whole lot of predictions. It can it can be powerful for certain things, figuring out how the virus is spreading, figuring out sort of when it's moving from place to place. Um but like a great example here is Jesse Bloom's group at the Fred Hutch, who's been doing these really powerful studies to map sort of which amino acids allow for escape from antibody responses. And then it sort of highlights types of mutations and in certain places that we can start looking for within the data that could give us an idea of um which of those lineages could end up being selected for by existing immunity.
